title: How Leaders Take Responsibility and Inspire Their Teams
description: It’s not just about getting your work done; it’s about owning the entire process.
author: David Finkel
excerpt: True leadership goes beyond finishing tasks to taking full responsibility, managing obstacles, and inspiring your team to follow suit.

html:
One of the most critical qualities a leader can demonstrate is ownership. Ownership goes beyond simply getting things done—it’s about taking full responsibility for tasks, projects, and outcomes, even when things don’t go as planned. As a leader, your ability to model ownership not only impacts the success of your team but also sets the standard for how your employees handle their own responsibilities. This article explores what true ownership looks like in leadership and how embracing it can inspire your team to do the same.

What ownership means

Ownership, in its simplest form, means taking responsibility for the work on your plate and following it through to completion. However, in the context of leadership, ownership takes on a much broader and deeper meaning. It’s not just about getting your work done; it’s about owning the entire process, from managing obstacles to acknowledging mistakes and ensuring the final product meets expectations.

Ownership isn’t passive. It requires proactive thinking, problem-solving, and a willingness to do whatever it takes to move a project forward. This might mean chasing down missing information, coordinating with other departments, or making tough decisions to keep things on track. Most importantly, ownership means being accountable for the outcome—good or bad.

How ownership inspires others

As a leader, your team looks to you for cues on how to behave in the workplace. If you demonstrate ownership and accountability in everything you do, your team will be more likely to adopt the same approach. Conversely, if you shirk responsibility, make excuses, or fail to follow through, you’ll inadvertently encourage the same behavior in others.

Here’s an example of what ownership looks like in action. Imagine a scenario where a project is delayed because one department hasn’t provided the necessary data. An employee without a strong sense of ownership might say, “It’s not my fault; I’m waiting on someone else.” While this may be true, it’s a passive approach that leaves the problem unresolved. A leader who models ownership, however, will take action by following up with the other department, finding alternative solutions, or escalating the issue to ensure it gets resolved in a timely manner.

By taking responsibility and finding solutions, you show your team that challenges are not excuses for inaction. This not only gets things done more efficiently but also fosters a culture of accountability, where everyone takes ownership of their role in the company’s success.

How to demonstrate ownership

  • Take responsibility for mistakes: One of the most powerful ways to demonstrate ownership is by taking responsibility when things go wrong. Mistakes happen in every business, but how you handle them sets the tone for your team. Instead of shifting blame or making excuses, acknowledge the mistake, analyze what went wrong, and communicate how you plan to fix it. For example, if a project fails to meet its deadline because of a miscommunication, a leader who practices ownership might say, “I didn’t communicate the timeline clearly enough, and that’s on me. Moving forward, I’ll make sure we have regular check-ins to avoid this.” Taking responsibility not only shows your integrity but also makes it easier for your team to own their mistakes without fear of retribution.
  • Follow through on commitments: Ownership means doing what you say you’ll do. Whether it’s a simple promise or a major project, consistently following through on commitments is essential to building trust and credibility with your team. When you commit to something, make sure it gets done, even if it requires extra effort or problem-solving along the way. If obstacles arise that prevent you from meeting a commitment, communicate openly and transparently with your team, explaining the situation and how you plan to address it.
  • Proactively solve problems: Ownership requires a proactive mindset. When issues arise, take immediate steps to solve them, even if they are outside your direct area of responsibility. This might mean coordinating with other teams, seeking advice from your supervisor, or finding a workaround until a permanent solution can be implemented. Leaders who model this behavior encourage their teams to think critically and take initiative when problems arise. Instead of waiting for someone else to solve the issue, they feel empowered to take ownership and find solutions themselves.
  • Support your team by owning their success: True ownership isn’t just about your personal responsibilities. It’s also about owning the success of your team. This means providing the guidance, resources, and support they need to perform at their best. When one of your team members is struggling, step in to help them find solutions rather than letting them flounder. For example, if an employee is falling behind on a project, you might offer to help them prioritize tasks or provide additional resources to lighten their load. By showing that you’re invested in their success, you build a stronger, more collaborative team.

Ownership and team culture

When leaders embrace and model ownership, it creates a culture of accountability and responsibility within the organization. Employees who see their leaders taking ownership are more likely to take pride in their work and hold themselves to a higher standard. This leads to increased productivity, better communication, and more efficient problem-solving.

In a culture of ownership, team members are more likely to take initiative, think proactively, and collaborate to achieve shared goals. They feel empowered to make decisions and take action, knowing that their leaders have their backs and will support them through challenges.

Ownership is one of the most powerful qualities a leader can demonstrate. By taking responsibility for your work, following through on commitments, and proactively solving problems, you set the standard for your team and inspire them to adopt the same behavior. In doing so, you create a culture of accountability, where everyone takes pride in their role and works together toward the company’s success.

As a leader, ask yourself, “Am I modeling ownership in my actions?” If you lead with accountability and responsibility, your team will follow suit, and together, you’ll achieve greater success. Start today by taking ownership of a challenging situation and see how it positively impacts your team’s performance and culture.
